title: Making the Web searchable

In particular how this relates to semantic search and that is using the metadata that we gather to improve the search experience of our users even further.

In particular, where you see that there are two main streams of work there is.

To clarify, with semantic Web we're talking about because one thing that semantic web researchers often argue about is is really what we mean by semantic value, and there are clearly two kinds of visions that drive us.
One is the vision of a data web where you're trying to bring databases to the web, so that's the link data movement where the data itself, where it comes from.
It's very originally described and we have rich schemas, and that's an interesting approach to tackle the deep web.
Problem that's, for example, search engines are facing.

There's another kind of context, and that has been actually had larger emphasis in some of the early semantic web work, and that is the idea of annotating the Web right of attaching metadata to web resources of trying to annotate the content of web pages using using ontologies.
And in this context, which is, for example, the context, very, very microformats operate.
It's very typical to find more lightweight solutions.
